tit.e: Jo (丈; a unit of length by old Japanese system of weights and measures) or Take (丈; height of people and objects.)
tit.cmt: 本項では読みの異なる二語について述べているため、併記しました。
tit.e: Jo (丈; a unit of length by old Japanese system of weights and measures) or Take (丈; height of people and objects.)

sen.j: 丈（じょう）
sen.e: 丈 (jo)
sen.cmt: 「丈」について、「じょう」と読ませる場合と「たけ」と読ませる場合がありややこしく又漢字そのものについて述べている箇所もあるので、「間」や「尺」と同じく英文中にも漢字表記を残した形にしました。又中国由来の箇所は読みを入れていません。
sen.e: Jo (丈)
Jo (丈)

sen.j: 丈（じょう）は、尺貫法における長さの単位である。
sen.e: 丈 (jo) is the unit of length by shakkanho (old Japanese system of weights and measures).
Jo is the unit of length by old Japanese system of weights and measures.
Jo is the unit of length by old Japanese system of weights and measures.

sen.j: 1丈は10尺と定義されている。
sen.e: 1丈 (ichijo) is defined to be 10尺 (jusshaku).
1 jo is defined to be 10 shaku.
1 jo is defined to be 10 shaku.

sen.j: 日本では、明治時代に1尺＝(10/33)メートルと規定されたので、1丈は約3.03メートルとなる。
sen.e: In Japan 1丈 (ichijo) is about 3.03 meters because 1尺 (isshaku) was defined to be ten thirty thirds meters in the Meiji period.
In Japan 1 jo is about 3.03 meters because 1 shaku was defined to be 10 over 33 meters in the Meiji period.
In Japan 1 jo is about 3.03 meters because 1 shaku was defined to be 10 over 33 meters in the Meiji period.

sen.j: 中国では1尺（市尺）＝(1/3)メートルなので、1丈（市丈）は約3.33メートルである。
sen.e: In China 1尺 (isshaku) (or市尺) is one third meters, so 1丈 (ichijo) (or市丈) is about 3.33 meters.
In China 1 shaku (or shi-chi) is a third meters, so 1 jo (or shi-zhang) is about 3.33 meters.
In China 1 shaku (or shi-chi) is a third meters, so 1 jo (or shi-zhang) is about 3.33 meters.

sen.j: 丈は古代中国に由来する。
sen.e: 丈 is derived from China.
Jo is derived from ancient China.
Jo is derived from ancient China.

sen.j: 「丈」は長い棒を手に持った形をかたどったものであり、そこから身長、身の丈（みのたけ）を表すようになった。
sen.e: 丈' was modeled after the shape of a hand and a long stick in it, whence it came to stand for body length, '身の丈' (minotake).
Jo' was modeled after the shape of a hand holding a long stick, whence it came to stand for body length, mi no take (身の丈; body length).
Jo' was modeled after the shape of a hand holding a long stick, whence it came to stand for body length, mi no take (身の丈; body length).

sen.j: 「丈」は元々は成人男性の身長を基準とした身体尺であったと考えられる（「丈夫」は元々は身長1丈の男の意で、そこから一人前の男の意となった）。
sen.e: It would appear that '丈' was originally the measurement unit of body length based on the length of adult male ('丈夫' originally meant a man whose height was 1丈 《ichijo;1.8 meters those days》, whence it came to mean 'fully grown man').

It would appear that 'jo' was originally the measurement unit of body length based on the length of adult male ('jobu' (丈夫) originally meant a man whose height was 1 jo [1.8 meters those days], whence it came to mean fully grown man).

It would appear that 'jo' was originally the measurement unit of body length based on the length of adult male ('jobu' (丈夫) originally meant a man whose height was 1 jo [1.8 meters those days], whence it came to mean fully grown man).

sen.j: 当時の尺は約18センチメートルであり、丈は尺と関連づけられてその10倍の長さとされた。
sen.e: 尺' was about 18 centimeters those days, so associated with '尺', '丈' was to be tenth the length of it
Shaku was about 18 centimeters those days, and jo was to be ten times larger, associated with shaku.
Shaku was about 18 centimeters those days, and jo was to be ten times larger, associated with shaku.

sen.j: 尺の長さが当初の倍近くになったため、丈も人の身長の倍程度となった。
sen.e: When '尺' became twice as long as the first length, 丈 also became twice the length of the body.
When shaku became twice as long as the first length, jo also became twice the length of the body.
When shaku became twice as long as the first length, jo also became twice the length of the body.

sen.j: 日本では大宝令以前から用いられてきた。
sen.e: It has been used since before Taiho Code in Japan.
It has been used since before the Taiho Code in Japan.
It has been used since before the Taiho Code in Japan.

sen.j: 近い長さの単位に間（けん;1間＝6尺）があるが、間が土地の測量や距離の計測に用いられたのに対し、丈は物の長さを計るのに用いられた。
sen.e: 間' (ken; 1間=6尺) is a similar unit of length, but while '間' was used for surveying the land or measuring the distance, '丈' was used for measuring the length of objects.
Ken' (1ken = 6 shaku) is a similar unit of length, but while ken was used for surveying the land or measuring the distance, jo was used for measuring the length of objects.
Ken' (1ken = 6 shaku) is a similar unit of length, but while ken was used for surveying the land or measuring the distance, jo was used for measuring the length of objects.

sen.j: 転じて、「丈」（たけ）は物の長さという意味にもなっている。
sen.e: In turn '丈' (take) took on another meaning, that is, the length of objects.
In turn '丈' (take) took on another meaning, that is, the length of objects.
In turn '丈' (take) took on another meaning, that is, the length of objects.

sen.j: また、1丈四方の面積のことを方丈（ほうじょう）と言い、その広さの部屋や建物の事も方丈と言った。
sen.e: Also, the area of square with side length 1丈 was called '方丈' (hojo), which also meant rooms or buildings with that size.
Also, the area of square with side length 1 jo was called hojo, which also meant rooms or buildings with that size.
Also, the area of square with side length 1 jo was called hojo, which also meant rooms or buildings with that size.

sen.j: 丈（たけ）
sen.e: 丈 (take)
Take (丈)
Take (丈)

sen.j: 丈（たけ）は、人や物の高さのこと。
sen.e: 丈 (take) is the height of people and objects.
Take is the height of people and objects.
Take is the height of people and objects.

sen.j: 例：身の丈
sen.e: For example: 身の丈 (body height)
For example: Mi no take
sen.cmt: 表記を変え前述補足を削除しました。
sen.e: For example: Mi no take

sen.j: また衣服の肩から裾までの長さや、スカート・ズボンなどの長さのことを指す。
sen.e: Furthermore, it means the clothes length from the shoulder to the base or the length of skirts and trousers.
Furthermore, it means the clothes length from the shoulder to the base or the length of skirts and trousers.
Furthermore, it means the clothes length from the shoulder to the base or the length of skirts and trousers.

sen.j: 股下2～3センチの従来型の半ズボンを三分丈、もも丈を四分丈、膝丈を五分丈、膝下丈を六分丈、すね丈を七分丈、くるぶし丈を八分丈と呼称する。
sen.e: Conventional short pants with 2-3 centimeter length of the leg are called '三分丈' (sanbutake), the ones with the thigh length are '四分丈' (yonbutake), half pants with knee length are '五分丈' (gobutake), the ones with low-the knee length are '六分丈' (rokubutake), pants with shin length are '七分丈' (nanabutake) and pants with ankle length are '八分丈' (hachibutake).

Conventional short pants with 2 to 3 centimeters in length of the leg are called sanbutake (literally, 30 percents of the whole length), the ones with the thigh length are yonbutake (literally, 40 percents of the whole length), half pants with knee length are gobutake (literally, 50 percents of the whole length), the ones with low-the knee length are rokubutake (literally, 60 percents of the whole length), pants with shin length are shichibutake (literally, 70 percents of the whole length) and pants with ankle length are hachibutake (literally, 80 percents of the whole length).

Conventional short pants with 2 to 3 centimeters in length of the leg are called sanbutake (literally, 30 percents of the whole length), the ones with the thigh length are yonbutake (literally, 40 percents of the whole length), half pants with knee length are gobutake (literally, 50 percents of the whole length), the ones with low-the knee length are rokubutake (literally, 60 percents of the whole length), pants with shin length are shichibutake (literally, 70 percents of the whole length) and pants with ankle length are hachibutake (literally, 80 percents of the whole length).

sen.j: かつてのように半ズボンと長ズボンしかなかった時代には業界用語だったが、ハーフパンツが登場し、微妙な丈の長さを表現するために消費者を対象に売り場でも用いられるようになった。
sen.e: 丈 was once a jargon when there were only short pants and longs, but with the advent of half pants the term came to be used at the stores to describe the subtle difference in the length of pants to the consumers.

Take was once a jargon when there were only short pants and longs, but with the advent of half pants the term came to be used at the stores to describe the subtle difference in the length of pants to the consumers.

Take was once a jargon when there were only short pants and longs, but with the advent of half pants the term came to be used at the stores to describe the subtle difference in the length of pants to the consumers.
